text.p: These are the main stories in Latvian newspapers on Tuesday. Prepared for Reuters by the Cooperation Fund. Reuters has not verified these reports and does not vouch for their accuracy:

- The board of the Latvia's Way party announced its strong objection to the plans of Prime Minister Andris Shkele to get rid of the post of state revenue minister, held by LW member Aija Pocha. The party pledged to prevent the move.
- The Democratic Party Saimnieks, the largest party in the coalition, has several candidates to the post of finance minister but will decide only after Aivar Kreituss finally leaves the post.
- The state audit office has prepared a report about Latvia's external debt. On January 1, 1996 the country's foreign debt amounted to 230.96 million lats.
- Deputy Edvins Inkens (Latvia's Way) was elected chairman of the parliamentary committee for European affairs.
- The parliament committee for human rights and public affairs has proposed to abolish capital punishment in Latvia and replace it by life imprisonment.
- Kreituss is not attending the annual meeting of the IMF and the World Bank in Washington. At the meeting his report will be read by central bank chief Einar Repshe.

- So far Latvia has not received any official reply to the proposals it made to Lithuania in the last round of border negotiations. Today Shkele will receive Latvia's plan of action if it receives no reply.

- Using false documents, two swindlers have stolen $102,000 from Saules Bank having transferred the money to one of Lithuania's banks. After spending a week in Spain, they returned to Riga and were arrested by police at the airport.
- An international seminar 'Business and the Environment', organised by the World Environment Centre (WEC) is taking place in Riga from September 30 till October 1.
